column4: installing linux on the rents' computer cause i'm tired of fixing windows every day.  can it run on 128 ram?  and can i install from the live cd without booting into the live part first?
You'll need 192 on it to use the livecd regular iso install. but it runs on 128 fine. You can install by alternate cd with less that 192Mb
No, the minimalistic installer just isn't on it unfortunately.
What I normally do actually is get the server install cd which goes to a cli install. Then I do a   apt-get install ubuntu-desktop   and then it just goes for the rest over internet
you mean run the server install cd from another pc on the network?

No, I mean use the server install cd to quickly get a basic system on the box. with little resources etc so usually successful. Then get whatever desktop you like installed  by way of the command apt-get install    kubuntu-desktop for KDE xubuntu-desktop for xfce or ubuntu-desktop for regular Gnome
will that install all the default packages and respective dependencies that are normally installed with the alternate ubuntu cd?
ok thanks.  their pc is a real heap.  celeron 466, 128 ram, 4 mb video... think i should install xununtu, or is that designed more to conserve hdd space?
Well, we have had a bit of debate earlier over that. but as for bang for the buck as goes a gui and usable, xubuntu is fine for something like that box is capable of
so will it run any faster that way?  is the only different the gui? xfce instead of gnome?
Basically the same sort of interface. in current xfce version tho, be warned is not intuitive how to make desktop shortcuts like in kde  or gnome tho.

Also by default gnome gdm login is installed, so you can put a minimalistic one if you like. i prefer wdm and then I uninstall gdm . It puts in a buinch on gnome stuff just to make the login screen pretty so I don't care to have it when I'm just going into xfce anyhow
second statement you lost me... i thought you were using gnome with a minimalistic login screen, then you said something about "when i'm going into xfce anhow"
wdm is a minimalistic x display manager. But even if you install only xubuntu-desktop for instance, it wants to pinstall a bunch of stuff gnome related just to give you gdm
ah ok.  either way i should use wdm though?  it's not gonna be passworded and there will only be one account other than root, so i'd set to autologin anyway
If only 1 account with autologin then you don't need a display manager. If it wants one by default then wdm is lightest.
